title: 106_s396
content: The "Dollars to the Classroom Act" is the short title of the Act. It directs certain education funding to states. The "Dollars to the Classroom Act" directs the Secretary to award education funding directly to states in accordance with specific provisions of law. The funds are those not used for certain programs under the Department of Education. The curr_chunk lists various education acts including the Educational Research, Development, Disseminations, and Improvement Act of 1994, School-to-Work Opportunities Act of 1994, Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and others (20 U.S.C.). The curr_chunk lists specific sections and parts of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C.), including Title III, Section 3132, Subparts 1 and 2 of Part A of Title IV, and Parts A and B of Title V. The curr_chunk provides a list of specific sections and parts of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, including various titles and parts such as Title VI, Part B of Title IX, and Part D of Title X. The curr_chunk lists specific sections and parts of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, including titles and parts such as Part D of Title X. The curr_chunk provides details on specific parts and sections of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, as well as timelines for conducting a census at the beginning of an academic year. The State conducts a census to determine the number of K-12 students each academic year. States must submit this data to the Secretary by February 1. The Secretary publishes the amount each State will receive for the next fiscal year by March 15. Funds are disbursed to States by July 1. The Secretary awards funds to each State based on the number of K-12 students, with penalties for submitting false information to gain additional funds. The State will not receive less than the correct amount under this subsection, with penalties for inaccurate information submission. The State will face penalties if it receives less than the specified minimum amounts for fiscal years 2000 to 2003, with decreasing percentages each year. The Secretary will use funds for fiscal year 2003 to make payments to eligible recipients under multiyear awards. Funds awarded to a State will be paid to the Governor, who will then make them available to the entity responsible for administering Federal education funds in the State. State administration of Federal education funds under State law allows for the use of funds to support K-12 programs, with a maximum of 5% for state determined activities. 20% of this 5% is distributed to local educational agencies for administrative expenses, while the remaining 95% is distributed to local educational agencies in the State. The State distributes funds to local educational agencies for classroom activities and services for K-12 students, excluding administrative expenses. Nonadministrative expenses related to statewide or districtwide initiatives impacting classroom learning are included. The Secretary of Education is prohibited from issuing regulations on classroom activities and services under this section. Each Governor of a State receiving assistance must submit a report on classroom activities provided under this section to specific committees within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Title I funding is addressed in Section 3 of the Act. Section 1603 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to ensure that at least 95 percent of funds allocated to local educational agencies are used for classroom activities and services, excluding administrative expenses. The Dollars to the Classroom Act requires 95 percent of funds allocated to local educational agencies to be used for classroom activities and services, excluding administrative expenses. The Secretary must develop a plan to streamline regulations and submit recommended legislation to Congress for this purpose. SEC. 4. Participation of children in private and home schools must be provided by local educational agencies receiving funds under section 2, following guidelines similar to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. SEC. 5. Definitions. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "local educational agency" is defined as in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and "State" includes various entities within the United States.
